HEADLINE: How to Find A Fund's True Colors

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
IS your mutual fund part of the problem in corporate America or part of the solution? Now that funds' proxy votes have all been filed, you can find out.
 Aug. 31 was the deadline for mutual fund companies to disclose which side they took in shareholder votes at annual meetings this year. Remember, most large funds battled fiercely to kill this disclosure requirement four years ago, when the Securities and Exchange Commission first proposed it. Luckily, the funds lost the struggle to keep their votes secret from the people whose money they manage, whose shares they vote and to whom they owe a fiduciary duty.
While funds are supposed to protect their shareholders, the sorry fact is that they often have lucrative relationships with companies whose shares they own on behalf of their clients. These cushy ties can be jeopardized if a fund votes against management's proposals or directors. 
 All funds say they vote in their shareholders' interests. But only an examination of mutual funds' proxy votes can determine whose interests -- theirs or their shareholders' -- funds are putting first. Let's take a tour. 
 Voting topics this year included the usual (director elections) and the unusual (management and outside stockholder proposals relating to corporate policies on board composition and executive compensation). So-called majority-vote proposals, which permit directors to keep their board seats only if they garner more than half the votes cast, were on many ballots this year; more than 40 percent of those voting, on average, backed the proposals.
 Executive compensation was also front and center this year. Some shareholders, for instance, proposed that companies be forced to retrieve executive bonuses if they turned out to be the fruits of improper accounting or fraud. Interesting, isn't it, that companies have to be pushed on such basic governance issues? 
 Still, some funds saw the light. Putnam Funds, for example, did the right thing when it withheld its support from directors who had approved excessive pay for executives who destroyed value at companies. It withheld support for all of Pfizer's directors because the funds' trustees were unhappy about the $83 million pension benefit and $65 million in pay that the drug giant awarded to Hank McKinnell, Pfizer's chief executive from 2001 until July. (Shareholders lost almost half the value of their Pfizer stakes on Mr. McKinnell's watch.) 
 At Pfizer's shareholder meeting in April, the company's directors supported him and said his pay was justified. But last month, Pfizer dumped Mr. McKinnell.
 ''To me, the Pfizer case was a slam-dunk,'' said John A. Hill, chairman of Putnam's board. ''We own the companies. If we don't act like owners, they won't treat us like owners.''
 Alas, among big, powerful mutual fund companies, Putnam is in the minority when it comes to acting like owners. Almost all the funds that are ranked among Pfizer's top shareholders voted to support the company's directors this year. Many did so against the recommendations of the proxy advisory firms they claim to rely on for guidance on shareholder votes. Glass Lewis & Company of San Francisco, and Institutional Shareholder Services of Rockville, Md., the nation's two largest proxy advisory firms, urged shareholders to withhold support from three Pfizer directors because of questionable pay practices at the company. 
 Mutual funds operated by Barclays Global Investors, Dodge & Cox, Fidelity and Northern Trust are among Pfizer's largest shareholders who supported its board. All receive revenue doing other work for Pfizer. 
 Officials at all four of these companies say their votes were cast in the best interests of their shareholders and in accordance with proxy voting guidelines. All say their votes had nothing to do with any revenue generated by Pfizer or other relationships with Pfizer or its directors. 
 Fidelity, for example, manages several funds in Pfizer's employee retirement plans. While Anne Crowley, a Fidelity spokeswoman, said the company does not comment on specific votes, she added: ''Our votes with management don't vary between whether or not we have another relationship with a company.'' 
 Barclays earned $2.65 million in 2004, the most recent year for which figures were available, as an investment manager in a Pfizer pension plan. Tom Taggart, a company spokesman, said: ''The sole factor B.G.I. considers in making proxy voting decisions is the best economic interests of shareholders.'' 
 Then there is Dodge & Cox, which earned $1.06 million in 2004 as an investment manager to Pfizer retirement plans. A Dodge & Cox spokesman, Steve Gorski, said its funds supported Pfizer directors in accordance with its guidelines. 
 ''Dodge & Cox has a long tradition of serving as fiduciaries and making decisions that we believe are in our clients' best economic interest,'' he wrote in an e-mail message. ''We normally vote proxies in support of company management, but vote against proposals that we believe would negatively impact the long-term value of our clients' investment.
 ''In the case of Pfizer's 2006 election of directors, we followed our policies and procedures and voted for all directors,'' he said.
 Richard Jurek is a spokesman at Northern Trust, which earned roughly $2 million from Pfizer in 2004 as trustee of its pension plan. He said Northern Trust's vote was made ''in accordance with'' Institutional Shareholder Services' ''vote recommendations to us that were in accordance to our proxy guidelines.'' 
 HMM. Which proxy voting guideline at Northern Trust transformed I.S.S.'s general recommendation that its shareholder clients oppose Pfizer directors into a recommendation that supported them? 
 Details of Northern Trust's guidelines are not published on its Web site and, at first, Mr. Jurek declined to make them available. He later provided them, explaining that they are given only to shareholders who request them. The proxy voting guideline that Northern Trust followed when it supported Pfizer's directors states: ''Northern Trust generally votes for director nominees in uncontested elections absent countervailing factors such as a lack of director independence or chronic, unjustified absenteeism.''
 In other words, no pay for performance disconnect -- not even an $83 million pension dispensed to a chief executive who presided over the destruction of billions of dollars in shareholder value -- is egregious enough to halt Northern Trust's rubber stamp for corporate directors. 
 It is thanks to this kind of large-shareholder passivity that we have seen the biggest transfer of wealth from owners to managers in the history of corporate America. And it is this kind of inertia that allows continued corporate wrongdoing. The fact is, too many fund companies have supported practices that betray shareholders but benefit corporate executives as well as the funds themselves. Only fund shareholders can stop this.
 ''Our society depends on checks and balances, and the money management industry has not done its part,'' said Frederick E. Rowe Jr., money manager and chairman of Investors for Director Accountability. ''It has enabled pervasive corporate abuses by voting its own economic interests instead of the interests of the millions of families whose money it manages. That is a betrayal. Investors should support those managers who properly perform their fiduciary duties and terminate the ones who do not.''
 Wander through your funds' proxy votes, which are usually on their Web sites. See how many times they voted your shares to support corporate managers and entrenched boards. Examine the issues they backed them on. If you think they are not serving your interests, fire them. 
 Otherwise, you will be enabling the enablers.

HEADLINE: The Bloomberg Vista

BYLINE: By Jonathan Mahler. 
Jonathan Mahler, a contributing writer, is the author of ''Ladies and Gentlemen, the Bronx Is Burning: 1977, Baseball, Politics, and the Battle for the Soul of a City.''

 BODY:
Mayor Bloomberg likes to eat out, and he makes an effort to have at least one meal a week in a borough other than Manhattan, often at restaurants that are more old-school than upscale. On an afternoon last month, he went to Bensonhurst, a working-class Italian neighborhood in Brooklyn, for lunch at the Vegas Diner. ''My ex-wife used to always have two different answers to the question 'What's your favorite restaurant?' '' Bloomberg said, studying the Vegas's oversize menu. ''What's your favorite restaurant if you're going to eat one meal before you die, or if you're going to eat all of the meals the rest of your life? I would pick a big Greek diner for all of the meals the rest of my life. All the food comes in 10 minutes, it's all the same price and it's actually not bad.'' 
The mayor had left his jacket in the car but was otherwise in his trademark attire: dark blue suit pants, black tasseled loafers, red tie and a monogrammed dress shirt -- MRB -- with Big Apple cuff links. A small, trim man, he looked well rested and energetic, despite the fact that he'd been up before dawn to jog on his treadmill after a late night out with his youngest daughter in George Steinbrenner's box at Yankee Stadium. 
 The mayor is by no means folksy, but he seemed surprisingly at ease piling coleslaw on top of Saltines and chatting with customers as he waited for his western omelet to arrive. He gamely, if a bit stiffly, raised his palm up for high-fives to autograph-seeking children -- ''How about a high-five for the mayor? Come on, you can do better than that!'' -- and parried chivalrously with a few elderly women who approached to pay their respects. ''I can't tell you how much I love you,'' said one. ''Women in their mid-30's like you are so smart,'' the mayor replied. ''I'm going to be 86,'' the woman said. Bloomberg feigned surprise. ''My mother's 97. You're a young woman!''
 That afternoon, the mayor was focused on new state legislation aimed at making it easier for workers who claim they developed illnesses while cleaning up the World Trade Center site to collect benefits. Bloomberg was conspicuously absent from the ground-zero press conference the day before at which Governor Pataki signed the bills into law, and the mayor then proceeded to denounce the laws as fiscally unsound.
 ''I have a legal responsibility to make sure the public's money is spent wisely,'' the mayor told me, stuffing a slaw-laden Saltine into his mouth. ''You're either going to have to raise taxes or cut services for this. We're talking about $10 to $15 million a year. Do you know how many teachers or firefighters you can get for that?'' The mayor pushed away his plate of pickles and coleslaw. ''We've got an insurance fund, and if we don't make sure that we only pay out legitimate claims, we're not going to have any money down the road. When I say you've got to show the damage was done to your worker, they say, 'Oh, well, we'll have them sign a paper.' Does anybody understand what's going on?'' Here Bloomberg lowered his voice to a whisper, as he often does when he's about to say something a little bit controversial, an unconscious tick that can drive his press secretaries crazy. ''In some agencies there's never been a person who retired without a disability claim.''
 If the mayor has grown more comfortable with small talk and quotidian interactions since he was first elected, in 2001, he has not lost his knack for staking out politically unpopular positions, particularly when it comes to emotionally charged, symbolic issues. And even five years after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, no issue is more emotionally charged and symbolic than ground zero. On the day that the mayor and I met for lunch, The Daily News, usually Bloomberg's most faithful supporter, called him ''coldhearted'' for opposing the new laws. A prominent labor leader told The New York Post: ''It's time for him to stop talking like a private banker . . . and start talking about human life -- like the governor.''
 It was perhaps inevitable that whoever succeeded Rudolph Giuliani was going to seem insufficiently passionate when it came to 9/11, but from the beginning, some have found Bloomberg's attitude toward ground zero jarringly unsentimental. Giuliani established a close bond with the relatives of the victims, appearing frequently at funerals and inviting families to participate in discussions of what kind of memorial would be appropriate on the site; Bloomberg was criticized for not attending enough memorial services and was wary of giving the grieving families a role in urban planning. (''These people shouldn't be deciding on the future of a huge chunk of a city,'' the mayor told me.) Whenever the mayor ventured his own thoughts about the future of the World Trade Center site -- warning against building too large a memorial or proposing that the site include residential buildings -- his comments invariably provoked controversy. More often than not, Bloomberg simply said nothing. He appeared uncomfortable with the sort of muscular, emotional rhetoric that ground zero triggered in other politicians. In the spring of 2002, a ceremony was held at City Hall to raise the famous flag that had flown over the smoldering ruins; no speeches were given. 
 Today when you talk to the mayor about ground zero, he will often steer the conversation away from the 16-acre site and toward the rest of the area around it, a neighborhood that starts north of the Trade Center site at Chambers Street and extends to the southern tip of the island. ''The press keeps writing about the World Trade Center site,'' he says, ''but if you look at a map, it's a very small part of downtown. The other part of Lower Manhattan, which is the vast bulk of it, doesn't get any attention.''
 The World Trade Center site is owned in its entirety by the Port Authority, and the leases to the buildings that were reduced to rubble on 9/11 are all held by a single private developer, Larry Silverstein. With no legal authority on the site itself, the mayor has opted to concentrate his efforts instead on the surrounding area, which was also badly damaged -- if psychologically and economically rather than physically -- on 9/11.
 But Bloomberg's emphasis on Lower Manhattan also reveals something more fundamental about his attitude toward ground zero. To many New Yorkers, whatever buildings rise on that hallowed ground will be our response to the terrorists, a statement of defiance and an expression of our ideals. Bloomberg's hope for these 16 acres is both more and less ambitious. To him, they are not important for what they say to the world but rather for what they could mean to a reimagined and re-energized Lower Manhattan, which in many ways embodies his larger vision for the future of the city.
 For decades, the story of Lower Manhattan has been one of seemingly inexorable economic decline. The city's business axis first began tilting toward Midtown before the Depression, when Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station started bringing in waves of commuters who preferred to work within walking distance of their train stations, not to mention all of the restaurants and theaters around Times Square. Innovations in engineering were giving rise to a new generation of taller skyscrapers with more usable floor space, larger windows, modern elevators and central air-conditioning, rendering Lower Manhattan's patchwork of low-slung 19th- and early-20th-century limestone-and-granite relics and cramped turn-of-the-century office towers obsolete. In the 1950's, the growing suburbanization of metropolitan New York and a postwar building boom concentrated almost exclusively in Midtown made downtown seem all the more anachronistic.
 In 1955, the banking scion and aspiring urban planner David Rockefeller tried to jump-start development in the district by placing the new headquarters of his family's Chase Manhattan Bank there. But the 60-story tower did little to stop the flow of business uptown. In the 1970's came Westway, a federally financed proposal to bury the West Side Highway and build above it a huge waterfront park lined with clusters of high-rises; it was defeated after nearly a decade of contentious debate.
 The World Trade Center was itself conceived to help breathe new life into Lower Manhattan by transforming it into the global center of international trade. Instead, the twin towers only exacerbated the neighborhood's problems, cannibalizing tenants from the rest of the financial district while pushing restaurants and retail stores underground and -- in unflattering contrast with Midtown's Rockefeller Center -- failing to provide any public outdoor space save for a wind-swept plaza. By 1995, about one-quarter of the offices in Lower Manhattan, roughly 20 million square feet, stood vacant.
 ''If you take a look at the concentration of financial firms downtown, the high point was before World War II, and it has been declining ever since,'' the mayor told me a few months ago. The principal architect of Bloomberg's effort to reinvent downtown is his deputy mayor for economic development and reconstruction, Daniel Doctoroff, a former investment banker who, in 1996, founded NYC 2012, the campaign to bring the 2012 summer Olympics to New York. ''Our vision for Lower Manhattan was in some ways a very romantic notion, and in other ways an unromantic notion,'' Doctoroff says. ''The unromantic notion was accepting that the place was a mess before 9/11. It's no coincidence that the mayor didn't put his company there. But there's also an opportunity because all of this money's going to be pouring in. So it was a matter of creating an opportunity out of a problem.''
 From the beginning of his tenure at City Hall, Doctoroff wanted to find a way to gain control over the Trade Center site -- he ultimately proposed an unsuccessful trade with the Port Authority: the two New York City airports for ground zero -- but he was confident that even if he failed, the city could transform the neighborhood by working around the 16-acres, nurturing its redevelopment not just as a financial district but as a mixed-use community. In the spring of 2002, Doctoroff started working on a new blueprint for Lower Manhattan. A number of city agencies provided input, as did a variety of architects and city planners, including Alex Garvin, a bow-tied urban planner and professor at Yale University who helped Doctoroff create a conceptual strategy for the city's Olympic bid. ''We know how to build memorials, and we know how to rebuild cities,'' Garvin says. ''But the problem here was different. The problem here was how do you grow a downtown, which was essentially slowly dying in its competition with Midtown and the rest of the region, around a memorial?''
 A little more than a year after his election, Mayor Bloomberg rolled out his vision for the future of Lower Manhattan at a breakfast of the city's leading businessmen in the ballroom of the Wall Street's Regent Hotel, a 160-year-old Greek Revival landmark that was once home to the New York Stock Exchange. Standing in the hotel's ballroom, a 12,000-square-foot rotunda that only a year before was a haven for 9/11 rescue workers and downtown's dispossessed, Bloomberg conjured a sort of utopian urban hamlet, ''a live-and-work-and-visit community for the world,'' with apartments and offices but also cafes, performing-arts pavilions, cultural facilities and public places. Tree-lined boulevards would replace the canyons of Wall Street, and the East River waterfront would be studded with ballfields, an outdoor ice rink and even a floating garden.
 ''Chuck Schumer says he wants downtown to be a vibrant financial center,'' the mayor told me this summer, referring to New York's senior senator. We were at City Hall, sitting in a vast 19th-century chamber that represents one of the mayor's first managerial innovations: neither the mayor nor his senior staff have offices; they all sit in cubicles in what was once this former hearing room. ''But there's real evidence that the future of downtown is not as an enormous commercial center. On the other hand, what does downtown have? It has phenomenal views, great mass transportation, beautiful old buildings that can be converted easily into residential. Now, does that mean companies can't stay down there? No, quite the contrary. I would argue that the reason most companies want to be in Midtown is because their employees can walk to work, go out to lunch to great restaurants. After work they can find taxi cabs, be entertained, go to the theater or a bar or whatever.''
 There is no model for the Lower Manhattan the mayor envisions. Unlike TriBeCa, its neighbor to the north, it will remain partly commercial, though it will be considerably more residential than Midtown. Because the island narrows so much at the tip, the apartments and office buildings will stand shoulder to shoulder. Most of Manhattan was built to face inward, away from the bustling, filthy waterfront; Bloomberg hopes to reconnect downtown to both the Hudson and East Rivers by encircling the neighborhood with a necklace of public parkland. 
 Partly to encourage downtown's evolution into a more residential neighborhood, the mayor has refused to offer aggressive incentives to businesses that are considering moving into, or out of, the area. Shortly after his inauguration, Bloomberg scuttled several hundred million dollars in subsidies that Giuliani had promised the New York Stock Exchange, which had been making noise about relocating to New Jersey, to help underwrite a new 10-story trading floor, topped by a 50-story office tower. (The N.Y.S.E. ultimately decided to stay, which hardly surprised Bloomberg: ''They're the New York Stock Exchange. Where were they going to go?'') The mayor gave Goldman Sachs about half the tax breaks it demanded to build a new $2 billion headquarters just west of ground zero, and he still regrets not giving the firm less.
 More controversially, the mayor has allocated hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of Liberty Bonds, awarded by Congress to the city and state after Sept. 11, for new apartment towers in Lower Manhattan, as well as new office buildings in Midtown and Brooklyn. The bonds were intended to help finance New York's 9/11 recovery, and Bloomberg has been accused of betraying their spirit. The mayor's critics also point out that downtown was undergoing something of a commercial renaissance when the twin towers were attacked: thanks to the bull market of the late 1990's, offices that had long been empty were filling with traders, brokers, bankers and lawyers.
 If Bloomberg is underestimating the commercial potential of downtown, the nation's historic heart of high finance, it is partly deliberate. According to the Federal Reserve, Wall Street continues to account for 20 percent of the city's earnings, which means that New York's economy is inevitably at the whim of the market. The mayor would like to reduce the city's dependence on the financial sector by encouraging residential conversions downtown and creating new commercial centers in other parts of the city. 
 But the mayor's ideas about the future of downtown are also a product of his own experience. Bloomberg started working for Salomon Brothers fresh out of Harvard Business School in a run-down building on Wall Street in 1966, hand-counting stock and bond certificates in an un-air-conditioned bank vault in his underwear, a task that has long since gone the way of the telegram and the mimeograph. His career in business traced the rise of the information age that contributed to downtown's demise; he made his fortune by developing a desktop terminal that allows brokers and traders to remain connected to Wall Street from anywhere in the world.
 Bloomberg says that what will attract companies to Lower Manhattan -- and, for that matter, to the rest of the city -- are not the imperatives of their industry but the quality of life. ''Companies come here because the people they want to employ want to live here,'' the mayor told me. ''I can look at my own business. We never would have been remotely successful anywhere else in the world.'' The city's job, then, is to make New York an appealing place to live. ''Cultural institutions, great parks, clean streets, safe streets -- those are the things that get the work force here.''
 The transformation of Lower Manhattan is now under way. Many of the old office buildings lining Wall Street are being converted into luxury apartments. In the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11, it seemed almost inconceivable that anyone would ever want to live downtown; today, it is the fastest-growing residential area in the city. There has been an influx of new stores, including a BMW dealership that recently appeared on the former site of an investment bank. Santiago Calatrava's $2.2 billion glass-enclosed train station, which planners hope will ultimately connect Lower Manhattan directly to J.F.K. and Newark airports, is under construction, as is a new, 12-line subway station and Hudson River ferry terminal. The extension of the West Side promenade to the Battery, the first phase in the reclaiming of downtown's waterfront, was completed in July. ''For 25 years, people have been trying to figure out how to bring people from the northern suburbs to Lower Manhattan,'' says Mitchell L. Moss, a professor of New York history at New York University and an informal adviser to Bloomberg. ''What we're seeing now is that downtown is being made into a place where people can work and live.''
 Some of this development would surely have happened without Bloomberg. Like the obsolete manufacturing lofts of SoHo and TriBeCa, the old office buildings of Lower Manhattan were ripe for conversion; the trend started in earnest under Mayor Giuliani. Still, even after just five years, it's easy to forget how uncertain the future of this neighborhood seemed in the wake of 9/11. ''People say, 'Oh, it's just market forces,' '' Doctoroff says. ''But people invest in an area because they believe in its future, and that requires articulating a vision and a plan that gives people hope.''
 It is impossible to separate the mayor from his personal fortune, and one of the clearest ways in which his wealth has manifested itself is in his senior staff appointments. For most mayors, hiring deputies is an exercise in rewarding political supporters and loyal foot soldiers. There is an element of quid pro quo to this, but it is also the most efficient way for mayors to insulate themselves against the hostile forces they will inevitably confront while running the city. The 2001 election was Bloomberg's first foray into politics; he had no political foot soldiers to speak of. What's more, he financed his own campaign, so he had no favors to repay. 
 As a result, Bloomberg has surrounded himself with an unusual group of senior staff members, including the 48-year-old Doctoroff. A Harvard graduate with a law degree from the University of Chicago, Doctoroff had virtually no political experience before joining the Bloomberg administration, and he and the mayor were only casually acquainted; Doctoroff had lobbied Bloomberg, then a private businessman, to help support the city's Olympic bid. 
 Bloomberg has also given his deputies an unusual amount of power, particularly compared with Giuliani, a notorious micromanager. This is not to say that Bloomberg is easy to work for. At a recent civic-association meeting in Queens, I heard the mayor publicly grill a commissioner for the Department of Buildings about a potentially unsafe construction site: ''You're telling me there's nothing we can do about it? When was the last time we had a building inspector there? Well, let's have another one there tomorrow.'' But as long as his senior staff can prove, in numerical terms, that they are producing results, the mayor lets them do their jobs and is happy to give them credit for their accomplishments. In Bloomberg's mind, no one deserves more credit than Doctoroff: ''History will show that Dan Doctoroff had a bigger impact on this city than virtually anybody.''
 Bloomberg and Doctoroff are, in many ways, kindred spirits. Both were born and raised away from New York -- Bloomberg grew up in suburban Boston, Doctoroff in suburban Detroit -- but started their careers in the city and quickly fell in love with it. Doctoroff also decided to go into government after first making his fortune in business. Before joining the mayor's administration following the 2001 election, he ran Oak Hill Capital Partners, whose largest investor is the Texas billionaire Robert Bass. Now he makes an annual pretax salary of $1. And like the mayor, Doctoroff has a reputation for being competitive and inflexible. ''Dan is not a guy who likes to go along for the ride,'' someone who has negotiated against him told me. ''He's an able guy who has been successful throughout his career and has always gotten his way.''
 Doctoroff lives on the Upper West Side, but when we made a date to meet for dinner a few months ago, he suggested an Italian restaurant in a converted 130-year-old drugstore in Clinton Hill, a recently gentrified brownstone neighborhood in north Brooklyn. Doctoroff is tall and athletic-looking -- he often bikes to work at City Hall -- but shortly after we sat down he told me he was on a diet. He had just made a $1,000 bet with a friend that he could lose 15 pounds first. ''I've done it before,'' he said. ''It's the only way I can lose weight.''
 Doctoroff ordered fish and a diet Coke and over the course of the next three hours proceeded to explain the mayor's broader development strategy for New York. For the most part, the plan grew out of a McKinsey & Company study revealing that the city's need for office space and housing was quickly outpacing its supply. According to McKinsey's estimates, the city would need an additional 70 million square feet of office space over the next 25 years; over that same period, more than one million people were going to arrive in New York. More people meant more amenities. The conclusion was self-evident: to continue to grow, the city was going to have to undergo a period of hyperactive development.
 Doctoroff set about identifying underused areas that could be repurposed. Here, the city's outdated zoning codes played to his advantage. Because New York's last comprehensive rezoning took place in 1961, when there were nearly one million more manufacturing jobs in the city, there were large tracts of idle land across the five boroughs. If necessary, Doctoroff figured, the city could employ its powers of eminent domain to condemn private property before turning it over to developers. ''You have huge swaths of the city that are no longer relevant to its economy,'' he told me, ''old piers on the waterfront, elevated freight lines, military bases like Governors Island, warehousing districts, rail yards.'' The approach mirrored Doctoroff's strategy for NYC 2012, which envisioned transforming neglected pockets of the city into sporting venues.
 The Olympic plan is dead, but signs of the Bloomberg administration's development strategy will soon spring to life around the city. ''We are literally dragging New York into the 21st century,'' Doctoroff says. A two-mile stretch of dormant Brooklyn property along the Greenpoint-Williamsburg waterfront was recently rezoned for housing and parkland; a decommissioned Navy port on Staten Island will be turned into apartment complexes, restaurants and a recreational sports facility; the crumbling Bronx Terminal Market will be demolished and reconstructed as a retail mall; the Atlantic railroad yards in Brooklyn may someday soon house the New Jersey Nets, as well as mixed-income apartments and 600,000 square feet of new office space. These are just a few of the dozens of development projects currently on the boards. All are contingent on the continuing strength of the city's economy. Most are years away from completion; some, like the Atlantic yards plan, face strong community resistance. But the mayor's office has already rezoned the equivalent of nearly 4,300 blocks throughout the five boroughs for commercial and residential use.
 It's not Bloomberg's style to speak in grandiose terms about these projects -- he is by nature more of a problem solver than a visionary -- and yet taken together, they do amount to a surprising vision for the future of New York. The popular cliche holds that the mayor governs like a modern C.E.O., and hiring McKinsey to help devise a long-term business strategy for the city certainly plays into that perception. But at the same time, Bloomberg seems to be trying to return parts of New York to what it was before it became a city of investment bankers and venture capitalists. By setting all of this development in motion, the mayor is seeking to sustain the city's growth -- and thus ensure that there will be housing and jobs for those who don't work on Wall Street. It was toward that same end that Bloomberg took control of the city's struggling school system and that he introduced New York's largest affordable-housing program in decades. 
 Bloomberg's New York is hardly a city where the children of civil servants will live alongside the children of financiers. It's far more economical for him to create affordable housing in the outer boroughs, which will no doubt accelerate Manhattan's evolution into an island of the wealthy, a trend underscored by the imminent sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, two large middle-class enclaves on the east side. And the mayor is by no means opposed to the sort of gentrification that has driven up prices in once relatively affordable neighborhoods like Harlem. ''If you're worried about gentrification,'' he says, ''don't improve the schools and don't bring down crime.'' 
 Still, the mayor's development strategy harks back to a less high-flying, more idealistic era in the city's history. His affordable-housing initiative, for instance, embraces New York's rent-control laws, a remnant of its social-democratic past. There is something incongruous about a billionaire entrepreneur championing, if implicitly, a return to a time when the city was more hospitable to the working class. For better or for worse, Bloomberg doesn't engage in self-mythologizing about his own lower-middle-class roots when he speaks about his plans for the city. ''What, I have to prove that my mother washed more floors than yours to prove that I have the legitimacy to address issues?'' he says. ''I don't think so.''
 Similarly, in reviving the city's long-dormant tradition of large-scale urban planning, Bloomberg is, in a sense, trying to reverse recent history. Ever since Jane Jacobs and her fellow urban warriors rose up against Robert Moses nearly a half-decade ago, an ethos of preservation and protection has held sway in New York. Unwilling to entrust the city's growth to gradual, organic forces, Bloomberg is opting instead for bold re-engineering. He and Doctoroff have clearly learned from the mistakes of their predecessors. Rather than heedlessly plowing under indigenous neighborhoods in the name of urban renewal, they have largely targeted derelict areas whose natural evolution has been retarded by the city's anachronistic zoning codes. Nor do their development plans include housing projects or monolithic commercial towers, which invariably create ghettos and destroy street life; they are geared instead toward what planners refer to as ''mixed-use complexes'' and ''24-hour communities.''
 Nevertheless, the mayor's ambitions can hardly be concealed, and his critics on the right would prefer that he leave development to the free market. ''We have such pie-in-the-sky ideas from Bloomberg,'' says Nicole Gelinas, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, an influential conservative research group. ''Meanwhile, the infrastructure that the city should be focusing on, like the subways, is being ignored. That's the real barrier our natural growth is going to bump up against.'' (For his part, Bloomberg told me: ''I take the subway. My attitude is go earlier if the train's crowded.'')
 Moreover, in a city as densely packed as New York, development almost always encroaches on existing neighborhoods; opposition is inevitable, as was the case with Bloomberg's failed plan to build a $2 billion stadium for the New York Jets, the centerpiece of his plan to create a new neighborhood of residential and office towers on a vacant tract of property on Manhattan's Far West Side. ''History will show that the decision on the West Side stadium was a disaster for the city,'' the mayor told me, reiterating his conviction that the stadium's retractable roof would have made it a popular venue for conventions and thus created countless jobs.
 To Bloomberg's critics, the stadium showed the mayor at his worst, callously disregarding public opinion and stubbornly refusing to build a consensus among his fellow elected officials. In the end, it was one of those politicians, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Lower Manhattan's representative in Albany, who delivered the fatal blow to the stadium, maintaining that the development of the West Side would impede the commercial rebirth of downtown. In fact, Silver says the city went so far as to actively steer businesses away from Lower Manhattan and toward the Far West Side. (Doctoroff denies this.) To Silver, it was unconscionable for the mayor to set his sights on a whole new piece of property in Manhattan rather than helping to replace the nearly 15 million square feet of downtown office space the city lost on 9/11. 
 It was almost a year ago that Mayor Bloomberg walked into a meeting with the Daily News editorial board and joined the ground-zero fray, calling for housing to be built on the site rather than offices and declaring that the city would be better off without Larry Silverstein there. ''Butt Out, Larry,'' blared a headline in The News two days later.
 Bloomberg's comments were unplanned, and they came as a shock to Silverstein and to Governor Pataki, who controls half of the Port Authority, the owner of the land, and was thus the lead politician at ground zero. The mayor's staff was less surprised: for months, he had privately been expressing concern about the site, which, for all of the post-9/11 urgency to rebuild, still hadn't been excavated. Only weeks earlier, the governor had scrapped two of the cultural institutions intended for the site after a number of the victims' families voiced concerns that they might mount exhibits that denigrate America. The foundation in charge of raising money for the memorial was several hundred million dollars shy of their estimated cost of $1 billion. ''Things were getting out of hand,'' Bloomberg told me, ''and nobody had the courage to stand up and -- well that's a little bit self-serving -- but nobody would stand up and say anything.''
 Eight days before Bloomberg's comments to The News, a Quinnipiac poll revealed that an overwhelming number of New Yorkers wanted the mayor, rather than the governor, to be in charge at ground zero. The World Trade Center site was obviously in chaos, but those sentiments seemed as much a measure of New York's confidence in its mayor as they were an expression of frustration with the rebuilding process. That impression was confirmed less than a month after the poll was conducted, when the mayor was re-elected in a historic landslide.
 Today, rumors persist that Bloomberg is considering running for president, his own coy protestations notwithstanding. (When I asked the mayor about this, he repeated his intentions to leave politics when his second term expires: ''It's very nice they play ''Hail to the Chief'' and that you have your own plane. For most people that's a big deal, but it isn't a big deal for me -- no offense, I hope you have your own plane someday.'')
 Given how popular he has become, it's easy to forget that only three years ago, Bloomberg's approval ratings were hovering at 30 percent, the lowest of any New York mayor in decades. The prevailing perception was that he was completely divorced from the experiences of everyday New Yorkers, and yet just self-righteous enough to tell them what was in their best interests.
 What accounts for this turnaround? The most obvious answer is circumstantial. When Bloomberg came into office, he inherited a $4 billion budget deficit -- $1 billion less than his own personal fortune but nevertheless a staggering sum -- and a local economy buffeted by Sept. 11. Economists were talking about the prospect of a fiscal crisis, and New Yorkers were imagining the rest: a return to the gritty, grimy 70's. New York is now booming: during the fiscal year that ended on June 30, the city recorded a budget surplus of $3.7 billion. The $85 million that the mayor spent on his 2005 re-election campaign also, no doubt, helped burnish his image.
 The mayor himself ascribes his newfound popularity to the fact that the city respects him for sticking to his beliefs. ''I am adamantly pro-choice, I am pro-gay-rights and have said a thousand times that I don't think it's the government's business who you marry, and yet I carried most Catholic communities,'' Bloomberg told me, referring to his re-election. ''And we carried the Upper West Side, an area where you'd never think in a million years a capitalist, running as a Republican, could win. That will be my legacy.''
 Bloomberg and his staff like to talk about his refusal to pander, which isn't to say that he isn't happy to exploit his views for political gain. On the eve of the 2005 mayoral election, Bloomberg came out against the confirmation of Justice John Roberts, citing the possibility that he might vote to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark abortion-rights decision that the vast majority of New Yorkers support. And in New York, a city that likes its mayors combative, talking about your unwillingness to pander is its own form of pandering. That said, it is hard not to admire the political courage Bloomberg has displayed in championing unpopular causes like the smoking ban, which he pursued with the zeal of a modern-day prohibitionist. Nor is there much doubt that by virtually every measure, New York is a better place to live and work than when Bloomberg first took office -- crime is down, the welfare rolls are shrinking, the city is experiencing a historic boom in construction. 
 The mayor has clearly settled into the job. He rarely flies off to Bermuda in his private jet for the weekend; instead he traverses the boroughs, marching in parades, visiting injured cops and attending funerals and weddings. He'll occasionally manage to get in a round of golf at one of the private clubs he belongs to in Westchester or Long Island, but he also speaks with firsthand knowledge about the city's public courses. During his first few years in office, he tended to avoid civic-association meetings whenever he could. He now seems to genuinely enjoy the feedback, and no complaint is too picayune to capture his interest. He's a regular caller to 311, the hotline he created so New Yorkers could voice nonemergency concerns, identifying himself simply as ''Bloomberg,'' before reporting some unsightly graffiti or uncollected garbage.
 Most of all, though, New York has gotten used to Bloomberg. New Yorkers have a unique personal relationship with their mayor. They expect him to be as much a mascot for the city, a personification of its particular spirit, as an executive. They want wisecracks, expressions of outrage, expressions of compassion, displays of emotion. These are not abundant in Bloomberg's repertory. While he seems much looser speaking publicly than he did during his first years in office, the mayor can still sound like a substitute teacher trying to relate to his class, reminding students to get good grades and to swim only when lifeguards are on duty.
 Not that the mayor notices. If Ed Koch, the archetype of the mayor as mascot, had an almost pathological need for affirmation, evidenced by his famous rhetorical refrain, ''How am I doin'?'' Bloomberg truly doesn't seem to care what people think of him. When Salomon Brothers was purchased in 1981, Bloomberg, who'd been with the firm for 15 years, was one of only a handful of partners fired rather than offered employment at the newly merged company, a seeming indignity that evidently didn't bother him in the least. The morning after his last day on the job, he started Bloomberg L.P., the eponymous media company that would make him one of the richest men in America.
 Even when his poll numbers were in the tank, he rarely expressed anything approaching regret about having decided to go into politics. ''There were days when I was furious about things that were written about me, I was furious about something I had said or about something that had happened, but I always get into bed and fall asleep instantly,'' the mayor says. ''You've got to look forward. You've got to get on with it.''
 To date, only one building leveled on Sept. 11 has been rebuilt: 7 World Trade Center, a sleek, soaring pale glass tower just north of the site, and therefore just beyond the reach of the architect Daniel Libeskind's master plan. It is hard not to see the building as a 52-story monument to the triumph of the free market over big government. And yet that perception is complicated by the fact that the historic skyscraper, which opened with great fanfare last May, remains about half-empty. 
 Silverstein Properties is the owner of 7 W.T.C. and is one of its seven tenants, occupying the entire 38th floor. Rather than taking a space on the north side of the building, which offers sweeping views of the Manhattan skyline and the Hudson River, the head of the company, Larry Silverstein, chose to be on the less-scenic south side, where he could monitor the rebuilding on the World Trade Center site. 
 The 75-year-old Silverstein's relentless optimism has carried him through seven recessions and a few brushes with bankruptcy over the course of his long career. The son of a Russian-Jewish immigrant and Lower East Side real estate broker, Silverstein bought his first building on East 23rd Street in 1957, picked up some used fluorescent lights for the lobby, slapped a fresh coat of white paint on the dingy walls and raised the rent 10 cents a square foot. A career as a real estate developer was born. Until recently, Silverstein's crowning achievement was signing a 99-year lease for the World Trade Center with the Port Authority in July 2001. Now his sights are set on something much, much bigger: rebuilding ground zero.
 The lone private developer in the tangle of interest groups at the site, Silverstein has come under frequent fire. While rescue workers were still sifting through the debris, Silverstein announced that he intended to move quickly on the rebuilding. Later, his decision to sue his insurers over their unwillingness to treat the attacks as two separate incidents cemented his reputation as the money- and power-hungry real estate developer who puts his own ambitions over the public good.
 At moments, the attacks on Silverstein have been unusually nasty. Charles Gargano, the vice chairman of the Port Authority, called him ''greedy.'' The Daily News ran a humor column parodying the developer: ''Oy. . .you think it's easy counting all that insurance money?'' Silverstein is unfazed by the criticism. ''There are a lot of naysayers out there,'' he told me in his office recently, ''and no shortage of people who would like to get their hands on one of these buildings. I heard that there were all kinds of developers talking to the mayor and governor, urging them to throw me out so they could come in.''
 Silverstein's immediate task is finding tenants for 7 World Trade Center, a job that has not been made any easier by the enduring physical reminders of the lack of progress at ground zero. On one side of the building sits the empty 16-acre plot; on another is the scarred, moldy shell of Manhattan Community College's Fiterman Hall, which was half-destroyed on 9/11 and remains untouched. But the rents at 7 W.T.C. are also high. Silverstein is asking for a little more than $50 a square foot, a steep sum when compared with the average price of $40 in most commercial buildings in Lower Manhattan, though still less than Midtown, where the going rate is $57.
 Months before the building was completed, Bloomberg was concerned about Silverstein's failure to find tenants for 7 W.T.C., and what that failure said about the developer's ability to rebuild the World Trade Center site. The mayor and Silverstein have an odd relationship. Bloomberg is close to a number of the city's high-profile real estate developers, polished, sophisticated men who belong to the same social and philanthropic circles as he does. Silverstein, who may be the only person who calls Bloomberg ''Michael'' -- most people call him Mr. Mayor; his friends call him Mike -- is cut from a very different cloth. The differences run deep. Bloomberg and Doctoroff, the former investment bankers, last year pressed Silverstein for cash-flow numbers proving that he had the funds to get all five towers built before he ran out of money. Silverstein hadn't figured everything out yet; he was relying instead on confidence and moxie, the stock in trade of real estate developers. 
 Much as he would have liked to, Bloomberg couldn't throw Silverstein off the site. The best he could hope for was to get him to surrender some of his control over it. Toward that end, he withheld more than a billion dollars' worth of Liberty Bonds that the developer was counting on. His administration also commissioned an investment bank to scrutinize the economics of Silverstein's rebuilding plan and used every opportunity to publicly question the developer's ability to build the five towers slated for the site before he ran out of money.
 The mayor's biggest obstacle to forcing Silverstein to cede some control was the governor. Pataki and Bloomberg had diametrically different priorities at ground zero. No matter what the mayor accomplishes in the rest of Lower Manhattan, his legacy will be bound up with whatever happens, or doesn't happen, on those 16 acres. The governor's final term was winding down, and as a likely presidential candidate for 2008, he was disproportionately invested in a single building, the symbolically resonant Freedom Tower. As long as it was rising toward the sky when he hit the campaign trail, Pataki could use ground zero to his political advantage. He had a compelling incentive not to lean on Silverstein, lest he wind up jeopardizing progress on the Freedom Tower. Pataki and the small coterie of old-fashioned political operatives who make up his inner circle were also worried, according to a former senior city official, that it might look as if the mayor were -- as the governor put it -- ''riding in on a white horse'' to rescue him. (Pataki's office denies that the governor said that.)
 Last spring, however, the governor agreed to join the mayor's campaign against the developer. In April, Bloomberg, Pataki and the Port Authority presented Silverstein with a new deal and pressured him to take it. Silverstein, his back against the wall, agreed to what were, in the end, relatively modest concessions. He retained control over three of the five towers and will build a fourth, the Freedom Tower, before handing it off to the Port Authority.
 From Bloomberg's perspective, though, it was a victory. Silverstein surrendered some of his power over ground zero -- enough, the mayor says, to get the site built. If everything goes according to plan, Lower Manhattan, which is already encased in scaffolding, will soon be the site of the largest urban redevelopment project ever undertaken. Over the next five years, 11,000 construction workers are expected to pack into downtown Manhattan, pouring 1.6 million cubic yards of concrete and raising 350,000 tons of steel at a total cost of roughly $22 billion, more than half of which will be spent at ground zero. 
 Substantial questions remain, however, including the consent of several of Silverstein's insurers. Until a final agreement is signed, the negotiations are not over. As Bloomberg knows, getting anything accomplished in New York is difficult under the best of circumstances, and the Trade Center site poses unique challenges. Outside ground zero, the forces arrayed against the mayor, from resolute community activists to ambitious political adversaries, are also estimable. What's more, the culture of preservation has strong roots in New York. While no one disputes that the city needs to adapt and grow, the handful of attempts to significantly alter the cityscape in the past half-century -- the twin towers among them -- have only vindicated opponents of large-scale urban planning. 
 In June, when I was riding uptown with the mayor to tour a newly renovated affordable-housing complex in the Bronx, I asked him what he thought was going to happen at ground zero. ''There will be continuing problems -- yelling and screaming -- but we'll get it done,'' he answered. He paused for a moment, as he gazed out the window of his S.U.V. at Van Cortlandt Park, where he won a controversial battle a few years ago to bury a water-filtration plant beneath the park's golf course. ''It ain't easy,'' he went on to say. ''If you want to get something done, you bring in one person and give him power. But the days of Robert Moses are gone.''

HEADLINE: Across the Great Divide

BYLINE: By JAMES GOODMAN. 
James Goodman, a professor of history at Rutgers University, Newark, is the author of ''Stories of Scottsboro'' and ''Blackout.''

 BODY:
THERE GOES MY EVERYTHING
 White Southerners in the 
 Age of Civil Rights, 1945-1975.
 By Jason Sokol.
 Illustrated. 433 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.95.
When it comes to the words and deeds we call history, time is merciless, laying waste to most everything that gets in its way. Consider the period from 1945 to 1975, the three decades of agitation and struggle known as the age of civil rights. That conflict touched every Southerner, and many Northerners, and it brought about changes as significant as any since emancipation. Yet today what remains is a list: one Supreme Court case, two federal laws, one march on Washington, several summers of riots and a series of dramatic confrontations, remembered as place names, from Montgomery to Memphis. White Southerners have it the worst: their list includes only the names of a handful of detestable men -- the likes of Strom Thurmond, Orval Faubus, Ross Barnett, Bull Connor, Jim Clark, Robert Chambliss, Byron De La Beckwith and Edgar Ray Killen. 
 It is the experience of white Southerners that Jason Sokol, who teaches at Cornell University, has chosen to explore in ''There Goes My Everything.'' He describes the men who filibustered civil rights legislation; stood in schoolhouse doors; met peaceful protesters and would-be voters with clubs, fire hoses and dogs; bombed black churches; and assassinated activists. He frames a chapter on the Civil Rights Act of 1964 around a portrait of Lester Maddox, the Georgia restaurateur whose defiance of the law (he and his white patrons chased prospective black patrons with ax handles and pistols) landed him in the governor's chair. Sokol eases into a chapter on political and economic change with a discourse on George Wallace. 
 But Sokol's real focus is on white Southerners who were less sure of themselves, men and women torn between past and present, old ideas (''Our Negroes are contented'') and mass protest. Away from the cameras and microphones, off the campaign trail, Sokol's Southerners give voice to confusion, mixed feelings and doubt. And many of them changed their minds. 
 One was a young North Carolinian, raised to be ''a racist'' but moved by Martin Luther King Jr. and black music (which his band played to segregated audiences). He fought discrimination on the high school football field, where he helped to protect his one black teammate from opposing players on all-white teams. 
 Another was a Florida motel owner. One week, he dumped hydrochloric acid into his motel pool to force black swimmers out. Two weeks later, he served black diners in his restaurant. Two weeks after that, under pressure from white supremacists, he again began to bar black diners. Klansmen firebombed his motel anyway. 
 A third was a pregnant New Orleans woman, already the mother of nine. Although she supported segregation, she defied the white boycott of a newly integrated elementary school simply because she couldn't bear the thought of her four grade-school children at home with her, ''squabbling and making noise and getting into trouble.'' After weeks of abuse from mobs and countless threatening phone calls, she didn't ''feel any freer than the nigra,'' and from then on she fought on their side. 
 Sokol has scoured newspapers, magazines, news bureau archives and oral history collections, and he uses what he found to evoke dizzying places and times: ''Where peaceful integration of public accommodations reigned in one town, blacks were refused service in the next. On a given city block, African-Americans could have doors slammed in their faces in one restaurant and encounter smiling waitresses next door.'' Wherever he looks, Sokol sees ''change, resistance to change and ambiguity.''
 Sokol is not the first to capture that complexity. His book is brimming with the duly acknowledged observations and insights of writers -- among them Robert Coles, Melissa Fay Greene, Diane McWhorter and J. Mills Thornton -- who have told nuanced stories about the white South. His notes and bibliography include the names of others. Nonetheless, our memories are short. There is always room for a good book, especially one written by a historian with energy and empathy -- and a really good ear.
 Unfortunately, ''There Goes My Everything'' is not that book. Five of six chapters are twice as long as they need to be. For every evocative anecdote and quotation, there are several others that are too familiar, merely cumulative or way off the point. Sokol's sentences are crisp, but he repeats himself so often that he risks turning his own insights into cliches. Worst of all, the book is wholly lacking in design: a messy subject is no excuse for a messy book. A historian must find the design that best expresses the mess. The possibilities are almost infinite, but a write-up of research notes is not one of them. 
 What a shame. In addition to many illuminating stories, there is a timely historical lesson adrift in these pages: people do not readily surrender power and privilege they assume is theirs in perpetuity. Many white Southerners, and a significant number of white Northerners, argued that the issue was not race but rights: states' rights, property rights, white rights. They complained bitterly that the civil rights movement violated them all. 
 It did. The movement violated all the rights -- all the power and all the privilege -- bestowed by man-made inequality. Or it tried to violate them. If only time treated inequality as it treats our memories of inequality, segregation and discrimination would have been gone long ago.


GRAPHIC: Photo: On Dec. 16, 1961, Martin Luther King Jr. led demonstrators through Albany, Ga., a town that became a civil rights battleground. King and many of the protesters were later arrested. (Photograph by Corbis/From ''There Goes My Everything'')

HEADLINE: HURRY! HURRY! 

BYLINE: By MARK A. STEIN

 BODY:
American Banker, a trade publication in New York, said it would present a lifetime achievement award to Angelo R. Mozilo, chief executive of the Countrywide Financial Corporation, noting that he had built the company from a start-up to the country's biggest mortgage lender. 
 Mr. Mozilo, of course, is also a champion of innovations like no-money-down adjustable-rate mortgages, some with low introductory ''teaser'' interest rates. With home prices falling and interest rates rising, many borrowers are finding themselves with higher monthly payments -- some even as their houses are now worth less than what they owe on them.
It is, one would think, a recipe for defaults in the relatively near term.
 American Banker said it would present its award to Mr. Mozilo on Nov. 30 at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan. 
 That is none too soon: in the second quarter, foreclosures in California, Countrywide's home state, rose at the fastest pace in 14 years, according to DataQuick. MARK A. STEIN

LENGTH: 1860 words

HEADLINE: More Muslims Are Coming to U.S. After a Decline in Wake of 9/11

BYLINE: By ANDREA ELLIOTT

 BODY:
America's newest Muslims arrive in the afternoon crunch at John F. Kennedy International Airport. Their planes land from Dubai, Casablanca and Karachi. They stand in line, clasping documents. They emerge, sometimes hours later, steering their carts toward a flock of relatives, a stream of cabs, a new life.
 This was the path for Nur Fatima, a Pakistani woman who moved to Brooklyn six months ago and promptly shed her hijab. Through the same doors walked Nora Elhainy, a Moroccan who sells electronics in Queens, and Ahmed Youssef, an Egyptian who settled in Jersey City, where he gives the call to prayer at a palatial mosque.
''I got freedom in this country,'' said Ms. Fatima, 25. ''Freedom of everything. Freedom of thought.'' 
 The events of Sept. 11 transformed life for Muslims in the United States, and the flow of immigrants from countries like Egypt, Pakistan and Morocco thinned sharply.
 But five years later, as the United States wrestles with questions of terrorism, civil liberties and immigration control, Muslims appear to be moving here again in surprising numbers, according to statistics collected by the Department of Homeland Security and the Census Bureau. 
 Immigrants from predominantly Muslim countries in the Middle East, North Africa and Asia are planting new roots in states from Virginia to Texas to California. 
 In 2005, more people from Muslim countries became legal permanent United States residents -- nearly 96,000 -- than in any year in the previous two decades. 
 More than 40,000 of them were admitted last year, the highest annual number since the terrorist attacks, according to data on 22 countries provided by the Department of Homeland Security.
 Many have made the journey unbowed by tales of immigrant hardship, and despite their own opposition to American policy in the Middle East. They come seeking the same promise that has drawn foreigners to the United States for many decades, according to a range of experts and immigrants: economic opportunity and political freedom. 
 Those lures, both powerful and familiar, have been enough to conquer fears that America is an inhospitable place for Muslims. 
 ''America has always been the promised land for Muslims and non-Muslims,'' said Behzad Yaghmaian, an Iranian exile and author of ''Embracing the Infidel: Stories of Muslim Migrants on the Journey West.'' ''Despite Muslims' opposition to America's foreign policy, they still come here because the United States offers what they're missing at home.''
 For Ms. Fatima, it was the freedom to dress as she chose and work as a security guard. For Mr. Youssef, it was the chance to earn a master's degree. 
 He came in spite of the deep misgivings that he and many other Egyptians have about the war in Iraq and the Bush administration. In America, he said, one needs to distinguish between the government and the people.
 ''Who am I dealing with, Bush or the American public?'' he said. ''Am I dealing with my future in Egypt or my future here?''
 Muslims have been settling in the United States in significant numbers since the mid-1960's, after immigration quotas that favored Eastern Europeans were lifted. Spacious mosques opened in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York as a new, highly educated Muslim population took hold.
 Over the next three decades, the story of Muslim migration to the United States was marked by growth and prosperity. A larger percentage of immigrants from Muslim countries have graduate degrees than other American residents, and their average salary is about 20 percent higher, according to census data.
 But Sept. 11 altered the course of Muslim life in America. Mosques were vandalized. Hate crimes rose. Deportation proceedings began against thousands of men. 
 Some Muslims changed their names to avoid job discrimination, making Mohammed ''Moe,'' and Osama ''Sam.'' Scores of families left for Canada. 
 Yet this period also produced something strikingly positive, in the eyes of many Muslims: they began to mobilize politically and socially. Across the country, grass-roots groups expanded to educate Muslims on civil rights, register them to vote and lobby against new federal policies such as the Patriot Act. 
 ''There was the option of becoming introverted or extroverted,'' said Agha Saeed, national chairman of the American Muslim Task Force on Civil Rights and Elections, an umbrella organization in Newark, Calif. ''We became extroverted.''
 In some ways, new Muslim immigrants may be better off in the post-9/11 America they encounter today, say Muslim leaders: Islamic centers are more organized, and resources like English instruction and free legal help are more accessible. 
 But outside these newly organized mosques, life remains strained for many Muslims. To avoid taunts, women are often warned not to wear head scarves in public, as was Rubab Razvi, 21, a Pakistani who arrived in Brooklyn nine months ago. (She ignored the advice, even though people stare at her on the bus, she said.) Muslims continue to endure long waits at airports, where they are often tagged for questioning.
 To some longtime immigrants, the life embraced by newcomers will never compare to the peaceful era that came before. 
 ''They haven't seen the America pre-9/11,'' said Khwaja Mizan Hassan, 42, who left Bangladesh 30 years ago. He rose to become the president of Jamaica Muslim Center, a mosque in Queens, and has a comfortable job with the New York City Department of Probation. 
 But after Sept. 11, he was stopped at Kennedy Airport because his name matched one on a watch list.

A Drop, Then a Surge
 Up to six million Muslims live in the United States, by some estimates. While the Census Bureau and the Department of Homeland Security do not track religion, both provide statistics on immigrants from predominantly Muslim countries. It is presumed that many of these immigrants are Muslim, but people of other faiths, such as Iraqi Chaldeans and Egyptian Copts, have also come in appreciable numbers.
 Immigration from these regions slowed considerably after Sept. 11. Fewer people were issued green cards and nonimmigrant visas. By 2003, the number of immigrants arriving from 22 Muslim countries had declined by more than a third. For students, tourists and other nonimmigrants from these countries, the drop was even more dramatic, with total visits down by nearly half. 
 The falloff affected immigrants from across the post-9/11 world as America tightened its borders, but it was most pronounced among those moving here from Pakistan, Morocco, Iran and other Muslim nations.
 Several factors might explain the drop: more visa applications were rejected due to heightened security procedures, said officials at the State Department and Department of Homeland Security; and fewer people applied for visas.
 But starting in 2004, the numbers rebounded. The tally of people coming to live in the United States from Bangladesh, Turkey, Algeria and other Muslim countries rose by 20 percent, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data. 
 The uptick was also notable among foreigners with nonimmigrant visas. More than 55,000 Indonesians, for instance, were issued those visas last year, compared with roughly 36,000 in 2002.
 The rise does not reflect relaxed security measures, but a higher number of visa applications and greater efficiency in processing them, said Chris Bentley, a spokesman for United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, part of Homeland Security. 
 Like other immigrants, Muslims find their way to the United States in myriad ways: they come as refugees, or as students and tourists. Others arrive with immigrant visas secured byrelatives here. A lucky few win the green-card lottery.
 Ahmed Youssef, 29, never thought he would be among the winners. But in 2003, Mr. Youssef, who taught Arabic in Egypt, was one of 50,000 people randomly chosen from 9.5 million applicants around the world. 
 As he prepared to leave Benha, a city north of Cairo, some friends asked him how he could move to a country that is ''killing people in Iraq and Afghanistan,'' he recalled. But others who had been to the United States encouraged him to go.
 He arrived in May 2005, and he found work loading hot dog carts from sunrise to sundown. He shared an apartment in Washington Heights with other Egyptians, but for the first month, he never saw his neighborhood in daylight.
 ''I joked to my roommates, 'When am I going to see America?' '' said Mr. Youssef, a slight man with thinning black hair and an easy smile. 
 Only three months later, when he began selling hot dogs on Seventh Avenue, did Mr. Youssef discover his new country. 
 He missed hearing the call to prayer, and thought nothing of unrolling his prayer rug beside his cart until other vendors warned him against it. He could be mistaken for an extremist, they told him. 
 Eventually, Mr. Youssef found a job as the secretary of the Islamic Center of Jersey City. He plans to apply to a master's program at Columbia University, specializing in Arabic. For now, he lives in a spare room above the mosque. Near his bed, he keeps a daily log of his prayers. If he makes them on time, he writes ''Correct'' in Arabic. ''I am much better off here than selling hot dogs,'' he said.

Awash in American Flags
 Nur Fatima landed in Midwood, Brooklyn, at a propitious time. Had she come three years earlier, she woul have seen a neighborhood in crisis. 
 Hundreds of Pakistani immigrants disappeared after being asked to register with the government. Thirty shops closed along a stretch of Coney Island Avenue known as Little Pakistan. The number of new Urdu-speaking pupils at the local elementary school, Public School 217, dropped by half in the 2002-3 school year. 
 But then Little Pakistan got organized. A local businessman, Moe Razvi, converted a former antique store into a community center offering legal advice, computer classes and English instruction. Local Muslim leaders began meeting with federal agents to soothe relations. 
 The annual Pakistan Independence Day parade is now awash in American flags. 
 It is a transformation seen in Muslim immigrant communities around the nation.
 ''They have to prove that they are living here as Muslim Americans rather than living as Pakistanis and Egyptians and other nationalities,'' said Zahid H. Bukhari, the director of the American Muslim Studies Program at Georgetown University. 
 Ms. Fatima arrived in Brooklyn from Pakistan in March with an immigrant visa. She began by taking English classes at Mr. Razvi's center, the Council of Peoples Organization.
 She has heard stories of the neighborhood's former plight but sees a different picture. 
 ''This is a land of opportunity,'' Ms. Fatima said. ''There is equality for everyone.''
 Five days after she came to Brooklyn, Ms. Fatima removed her head scarf, which she had been wearing since she was 10. She began to change her thinking, she said: She liked living in a country where people respected the privacy of others and did not interfere with their religious or social choices. 
 ''I came to the United States because I want to improve myself,'' she said. ''This is a second birth for me.''

HEADLINE: Iraqi Premier Will Visit Iran to 'Enhance' Ties

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG; An Iraqi employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Kirkuk.

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki plans to visit Iran on Monday to discuss security and political matters with Iranian leaders, his spokesman said Saturday. The visit would be the first by Mr. Maliki to Iran since he took office in late May.
 The visit is expected to last two days. A delegation led by Barham Salih, a deputy prime minister, traveled to Iran last week to pave the way for Mr. Maliki's visit. Mr. Maliki lived for some time in Tehran, the Iranian capital, while in exile during Saddam Hussein's rule. 
The purpose of Mr. Maliki's visit is to ''enhance relationships between the two countries,'' his spokesman, Ali al-Dabagh, said in a written statement.
 Any relationship between Iraq and Iran should be ''based on mutual interests and the respect of the sovereignty of the two countries and noninterference in internal affairs,'' Mr. Dabagh said. 
 American and Sunni Arab officials have long accused Iran, a Shiite-ruled country, of interfering in political and military affairs here. Many of the religious Shiite parties now in power in Iraq, including Mr. Maliki's Islamic Dawa Party, have close ties to Iran. But ordinary Iraqis are generally suspicious of Iran, whose ethnic Persians have traditionally rivaled Arabs for influence in this region.
 Ibrahim al-Jaafari, the former prime minister and head of Dawa, visited Iran while he was in office. The head of the main Shiite bloc in Parliament, Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, is considered extremely close to Iran's top leaders. His party was founded in Iran and its armed wing, the Badr Brigade, fought against Iraq in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war in the 1980's.
 On Friday, an Interior Ministry official said Iranian troops had arrested five members of the Iraqi security forces and their interpreter last week while the Iraqis were patrolling the Iraq-Iran border northeast of Baghdad. The official Iranian news agency said seven Iraqis had been captured.
 The American ambassador, Zalmay Khalilzad, and American commanders strongly condemned Iranian interference in Iraq last month, saying they had evidence that individuals or groups in Iran were training and supporting Shiite militias here. Mr. Khalilzad said Iranians were urging militia groups to step up attacks against the Americans.
 The United States has been pressing Iran over its nuclear program as well. The Bush administration is urging the United Nations Security Council to pass a resolution that would impose economic and political sanctions on Iran if Iran persists in its uranium enrichment program, which the Americans say is intended for the manufacture of nuclear weapons.
 But it would be difficult for the White House to persuade Iraq to take a strong stand against Iran. Besides the political ties among Shiite politicians, the border is very porous, and Shiite pilgrims from Iran often come to Iraq to mingle freely in the religious cities here. Iranians helped make up the hundreds of thousands of Shiites, possibly millions, who gathered in the city of Karbala on Saturday to celebrate the birthday of a vanished Shiite imam known as the Mahdi.
 Three pilgrims en route to Karbala were killed in the town of Musayyib by a mortar round, an Interior Ministry official said.
 In Baghdad, gunmen killed a secretary for a government-financed newspaper, Al Sabah, in a drive-by shooting. A minibus driver was killed when his vehicle exploded. A bomb in a parked car killed a policeman and wounded six others, and another bomb exploding near an American convoy killed one civilian and wounded at least six.
 A homemade bomb that was detonated near a bakery in Kirkuk killed three civilians, two of them children, and wounded eight others, all women and children, police officials said. Another bomb in the city killed a policeman and wounded two others.

HEADLINE: European Union in Last-Ditch Talks With Iran on Nuclear Plans

BYLINE: By JUDY DEMPSEY

DATELINE: BERLIN, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign policy chief and Ali Larijani, Iran's top nuclear negotiator, said Saturday that they would continue last-ditch negotiations on Sunday in Vienna to see how far Iran would go to meet United Nations Security Council demand that it freeze its uranium-enrichment program or risk sanctions. 
 Christina Gallach, Mr. Solana's spokeswoman, told reporters that the three hours of talks on Saturday had been ''positive and constructive.'' Mr. Larijani said, ''We had some good and constructive talks, we made some progress in some areas, and we shall continue tomorrow.''
Diplomatic pressure on Iran to halt its enrichment of uranium has increased in recent weeks. Iran says its nuclear program is designed to generate electricity, but the United States and Europe suspect the program is meant to develop nuclear weapons. 
 R. Nicholas Burns, the American under secretary of state for political affairs, said Friday in Berlin that the United States hoped to begin talks next week to fashion a resolution that would seek sanctions against Iran if it did not halt its enrichment of uranium. 
 Mr. Burns was speaking after extensive talks with the other four permanent members of the Security Council -- Russia, France, China, Britain -- as well as with Germany. Talks were held separately with Canada, Italy and Japan.
 He said the talks with the Europeans, Russia and China would continue Monday and would focus on the possibility of drawing up a draft on sanctions before the General Assembly convened the following week.
 But Russia and China have made it clear that they will oppose sanctions, and on Saturday, the Chinese prime minister, Wen Jaibao, warned against stepping up pressure on Iran. 
 ''To mount pressure or to take sanctions will not necessarily bring about a peaceful solution,'' he told a news conference in Helsinki, Finland, after a meeting with European Union officials. He added that resolving the nuclear dispute peacefully would take time. 
 Mr. Wen will start a two-day official visit to Germany on Wednesday, and is expected to discuss Iran with the German chancellor, Angela Merkel. 
 Before arriving in Vienna, Mr. Solana said he did not want United Nations sanctions to be imposed on Iran ''as long as meetings with Mr. Larijani continue.'' 
 Britain, France and Germany circulated a letter to other European capitals on Thursday warning that Iran was intent on ''splitting the international community'' and playing for time by declining to answer in detail a package of economic and political incentives that American, European, Russian and Chinese negotiators presented it in July.
