HEADLINE: Where Clean and Friendly Always Work 

BYLINE: By JEFF BAILEY

 BODY:
PENNY-PINCHING corporate travel departments and miserly per diems have made life miserable. But a boom in lower-priced lodgings -- and spirited competition among economy chains -- has helped lift the quality of rooms at many budget hotels and motels.
 Stay in a roadside motel on business travel? 
Millions do, especially outside major metropolitan areas, away from the Ritz-Carltons and the Marriotts.
 At Super 8, the country's biggest economy chain, with about 2,000 motels, each of its roughly 124,000 rooms now has a free wireless Internet connection. And curved shower rods -- they hold the curtain away from a wet body -- are being installed, too.
 The rates are cheap. Super 8 charged an average of about $53 a night last year. A full-service Marriott room went for about $150 a night. Marriott's high-end chain, Ritz-Carlton, collected about $288 per room per night.
 The price difference does not stop there. Internet access and continental breakfast are free at Super 8 and at many of its competitors. 
 ''That's the crazy thing,'' said Paul Pettit, president of Eastern Hospitality Management, a franchisee that operates 40 Super 8's. ''You go to these fancy places and they ding you for everything.''
 A full-service Marriott, for instance, typically charges $12.95 a night for a package that includes Internet access and local and long-distance calls, said John Wolf, a spokesman. Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts charges about $10 a night for Internet use, said Nicola Blazier, a spokeswoman.
 Prices at economy chains have risen less rapidly than those at higher-end lodgings, reflecting overbuilding in recent years, which led to a glut of lower-priced rooms.
 Super 8's blanket the countryside but also ring many large cities. A few are even inside the big cities. Houston has seven. Los Angeles has four. Chicago, San Francisco and New York each has one.
 The chain is also expanding in China, a country that lacks lodging for business travelers outside major commercial centers.
 Among American corporations, truck drivers have long been directed to stay in economy-class lodging, which includes chains like Motel 6, Red Roof Inns, Days Inn, Econo Lodge, Rodeway Inns and Travelodge, said Maria Chevalier, a vice president at BCD Travel Consulting in Atlanta.
 But as cost consciousness has spread through corporate America, and as hotel rates have risen sharply the last two years, more lower- and middle-level managers traveling on business are being told to stay at the likes of Super 8, Ms. Chevalier said. 
 Regular Super 8 customers include major companies like Wal-Mart, Home Depot, Cardinal Health and Deloitte & Touche.
 ''We use Super 8,'' said Jerry Shields, a Home Depot spokesman. ''We're constantly looking for the most economical means of travel that matches our business needs.''
 The first Super 8 opened in 1974 in Aberdeen, S.D. The fall pheasant-hunting season conveniently helped fill the place up. Lacking money for market research, the founders, Dennis Brown and Ron Rivett, tried to locate early Super 8's near Holiday Inns, thinking that the chain knew what it was doing, a company history says.
 The founders wanted to attract business travelers willing to spend a little more than Motel 6 first charged, $6.66, and priced Super 8 at $8.88 for a single room.
 ''The road warrior,'' explained Mr. Pettit, the operator of 40 Super 8's. ''He's a salesman, driving his car, calling on larger businesses in town, typically not on a per diem -- he's paying his own way. Clean and friendly always works.''
 The chain sold franchises, grew to 1,000 motels in the early 90's, was bought by a larger lodging company and doubled in size to about 2,000 outlets earlier this decade.
 Super 8's parent company, Wyndham Worldwide, was spun off as a separate publicly traded corporation in July by the Cendant Corporation.
 After a long period of rapid growth, Super 8 has spent the last three years trying to raise quality and, in some cases, weeding out poor-performing franchisees, said John Valletta, the chain's president. ''Some of them had to go,'' he said, because a traveler having a bad experience at just one motel in the chain will most likely stop staying at any Super 8 location.
 Mattresses and towels are being upgraded. A loyalty program provides points that can be redeemed at restaurants like Denny's and Olive Garden, merchants that include Blockbuster and Home Depot and amusement parks like Six Flags. 
 About 65 percent of Super 8 guests show up without a reservation. Of the roughly 35 percent who make a reservation, most do so the day they plan to check in. ''Forecasting is very difficult,'' Mr. Valletta said. But with a chainwide occupancy rate of 54 percent last year, most nights there were plenty of available rooms.
 Business travelers account for about half of the chain's revenue, Mr. Valletta said. Of course, the business traveler wants a clean room, quick check-in and a friendly face at the front desk. 
 ''I look at every complaint that comes in,'' Mr. Pettit said. A new e-mail quality survey is helping him spot problem motels sooner, he said. ''You put a new manager in there, and you can watch the scores improve.''
 Beyond breakfast, Super 8's do not serve food. But restaurants are usually close. ''It might be a waffle house,'' Mr. Pettit said.
 Dhirendra Dhir, who with his wife owns and operates two Super 8's in Wisconsin, runs a free shuttle between one of the motels and the Milwaukee airport and allows guests who stay at least one night to leave cars in his parking lot for at least 14 days.
 Truck and rail terminals close by combine to rent ''easily 25 to 30 rooms every day,'' he said. Business travelers visiting a nearby Wal-Mart and traveling state employees also account for many rooms.
 Upgrades mandated by Wyndham -- Internet access, shower rods, mattresses and such -- pay for themselves, Mr. Dhir said, in higher room rates and higher occupancy. ''We make sure that they are very happy.''

HEADLINE: 2 Vying for Governor Back Plan for Public Agencies as Anchor Tenants in Freedom Tower

BYLINE: By SEWELL CHAN

 BODY:
The two major candidates for governor of New York gave their support yesterday to a new agreement under which federal and state agencies would become the anchor tenants of the Freedom Tower under construction at ground zero. 
 The endorsement by the two candidates, Eliot Spitzer and John Faso, is a step forward for the project, the centerpiece of the reconstruction effort in Lower Manhattan, because it signals that whoever wins the general election in November is likely to continue Gov. George E. Pataki's plans for the skyscraper.
Under an agreement announced yesterday by Mr. Pataki and Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, along with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, federal and state agencies will occupy about 1 million of the 2.6 million square feet in the building, which is being developed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 
 Mr. Spitzer, the state attorney general, who holds a strong lead in opinion polls and in fund-raising, has questioned the timetable for the project, calling it unrealistic. The project has been hobbled by delays because of disputes over design and security, and questions as to the economic necessity of the building. Meanwhile, construction costs have risen. 
 But yesterday, Mr. Spitzer said the new agreement was a sign of progress. ''I am pleased that Governor Pataki has secured the one million square feet of government tenancy, which is a crucial step in ensuring the financial viability of the Freedom Tower,'' he said through a campaign spokeswoman, Christine Anderson.
 Mr. Faso's campaign also welcomed the news of the agreement. ''This is a good step in the right direction,'' a campaign spokeswoman, Susan Del Percio, said yesterday.
 Mr. Bloomberg, who has at times been frustrated by the limited scope of his authority at ground zero, said the announcement took the city ''another significant step closer to our goal of restoring the World Trade Center site as a hub of commerce in Lower Manhattan.''
 Not everyone was as enthusiastic about the announcement. 
 ''This is clearly not an economic decision, but a political decision,'' said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group that has monitored land use and development in the region since 1922. ''It really is about symbolism and politics.'' 
 The completion of the World Trade Center in the early 1970's added 10 million square feet of office space to Lower Manhattan and depressed the commercial real estate market for years. The Freedom Tower, along with three other towers, to be built along Church Street, is expected to add at least eight million square feet of office space. 
 ''When the World Trade Center was built almost 40 years ago, the government was a growth industry and you could fill up the trade center with government offices, but clearly we're not in a period like that,'' Mr. Yaro said. 
 Under the agreement, Customs and Border Protection, part of the United States Department of Homeland Security, will be one of the federal agencies in the Freedom Tower. ''Homeland security may be the one growth area in government,'' Mr. Yaro said. ''Maybe they'll need more space.'' 
 Eric J. Deutsch, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, the business improvement district in Lower Manhattan, was more optimistic about the new announcement. ''It's an enormous step forward, a catalyst in getting the project built,'' he said.
 The area had about 110 million square feet of office space before the 9/11 attacks and now has about 85 million, Mr. Deutsch estimated. ''Adding eight million square feet over the next six years doesn't necessarily create a damper on the market,'' he said. ''The economy has picked up in Lower Manhattan, office rents are moving up, vacancy rates are moving down and Class A office space creates a more modern, competitive and effective central business district.''
 Both Mr. Faso and Mr. Spitzer have pledged to honor Mr. Pataki's commitment to moving the governor's New York City offices into the Freedom Tower. Both have said that state agencies already paying market rents for other space in Manhattan should consider moving into the building. 
 ''There is no reason that state government offices need to be taking up prime commercial space in Midtown -- as the executive offices and the Empire State Development Corporation do right now -- when the Freedom Tower may provide high-quality space at competitive prices,'' Mr. Spitzer said in a statement in July. 
 Whether government employees will want to work in the Freedom Tower remains an open question. The Port Authority, which lost 84 employees in the 9/11 attack, has said it would be too traumatic to have its headquarters employees work in the building. 
 Because of concerns raised by the Police Department, the Freedom Tower was redesigned to have a huge fortified concrete base. But the proposed height -- 1,776 feet including the antenna -- and prominent location are still sources of anxiety for potential tenants. 
 Stu Loeser, a spokesman for Mayor Bloomberg, said, ''This will be the world's safest office building, and this announcement moves us forward to building it.'' 
 Asked if the mayor would consider relocating city agencies to the Freedom Tower, Mr. Loeser said, ''When we have an announcement to make, we'll make it.''

HEADLINE: 'Bold Moves' At Ford Not Bold Enough For Wall St.

BYLINE: By NICK BUNKLEY; Micheline Maynard contributed reporting from Detroit.

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Its commercials assure car shoppers that the Ford Motor Company embodies ''bold moves.''
 Yet analysts saw little evidence of that emanating from Ford's headquarters here last week as the company unveiled its latest revamping vision, in which it called for 44,000 job cuts, acknowledged that it would not make a profit in North America until 2009 at the earliest and conceded that it could not keep up with its surging Japanese rival Toyota.
For all of the stunning admissions Ford made, Wall Street wanted more answers. Ford's stock price, which rose steadily the last few weeks in anticipation of a broader announcement, fell nearly 12 percent Friday as analysts downgraded the company and criticized its turnaround plan. 
 ''It's missing a lot,'' wrote John Murphy, a Merrill Lynch automotive analyst in New York, who dropped his rating of Ford to sell from neutral.
 Ford executives, who seemed surprised by the immediate and widespread disapproval, defended their announcement in an interview last week. ''We're laying a foundation for profitable growth down the road,'' said Mark Fields, president of Ford's Americas group.
 Still, they realize that this is Ford's third turnaround attempt in five years. The latest is a faster-paced revision of a reorganizing effort called the Way Forward that was laid out in January, and the consequences of failing have grown exponentially.
 ''This plan, in tone, sounds a lot like the January plan, and the January plan didn't work,'' said John Casesa, managing partner of Casesa Strategic Advisers in New York.
 ''They've got to make this work,'' Mr. Casesa added, ''because they won't have another chance.''
 Mr. Fields and Alan R. Mulally, the company's new chief executive, are charged with making it work. Mr. Fields, who was appointed to his position shortly before the original Way Forward announcement, avoided becoming a scapegoat for the company's failure to anticipate how severely high gasoline prices would cut into sales of sport utility vehicles and pickups.
 But Mr. Fields must prove that he has the mettle to execute the new plan successfully, and he risks being forced out if he cannot. Conversely, if the turnaround takes hold, credit will undoubtedly be given to Mr. Mulally, who came to Ford from Boeing, the jet maker.
 Despite hiring Mr. Mulally as chief executive instead of promoting Mr. Fields, the chairman of Ford, William Clay Ford Jr., has faith in Mr. Fields and believes that he will benefit from working with Mr. Mulally, a skilled executive with experience in turnarounds, according to a person with direct knowledge of Mr. Ford's thinking.
 Executives at Ford know that ''time is not our friend; if we don't make the tough decisions, they get imposed on us,'' said a person involved in strategy sessions with the company's senior management. ''We have fewer and fewer options as time presses on,'' said this person, who asked not to be identified because the discussions were confidential, ''but at least we're taking action.''
 The makeup of the team that will assist Mr. Fields and Mr. Mulally is in question, particularly after Anne Stevens, Mr. Fields's chief operating officer, announced her retirement last week. Mr. Mulally, so far, has not said whom he might recruit from Boeing, but there is talk that Ford's chief financial officer, Don R. Leclair, will not be in his job for long.
 Mr. Leclair appeared to lack energy as he participated in Friday's announcement, which was broadcast to reporters and analysts only on the Internet and by phone, but his defense of the turnaround plan in subsequent days has been spirited.
 Rampant speculation about the automaker's intentions have apparently skewed outsiders' perspectives, he said in an interview.
 ''I think sometimes expectations get ahead of schedule,'' said Mr. Leclair, who noted that Ford's shares were worth more now than two months ago, when Mr. Ford acknowledged that the original plan had to be accelerated.
 Among the actions analysts have anticipated, but that Ford did not say it would take, are the sale of noncore assets, faster product introductions and deeper capacity reductions. Ford had previously said it was exploring a sale of its British sports car brand, Aston Martin, but on Friday insisted that it was not looking to unload its money-losing Jaguar brand, its weakened Mercury brand or a stake in its credit operations. Those are steps that many industry observers deem necessary.
 ''When the ship starts to sink, you have to start throwing things overboard,'' said James Brock, a professor of economics at the Farmer School of Business at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.
 Meanwhile, adding insult to Ford's concession that it will no longer be the second-largest seller of vehicles in the United States after General Motors was a report over the weekend that Toyota intended to increase production outside Japan to five million vehicles by 2008. Ford was outsold by Toyota in the United States for the first time ever in July and now says its market share will settle at around 15 percent, a level Toyota is expected to surpass soon.
 ''You had the pioneer in the mass automotive industry, Henry Ford, behind this company,'' Mr. Brock said wistfully. ''Hopefully, there may be some of that DNA still in the organization so that these guys can somehow pull together and figure out how to do this.''

HEADLINE: Skip the Test, Betray the Cause

BYLINE: By Colin S. Diver. 
Colin S. Diver is the president of Reed College.

DATELINE: Portland, Ore. 

 BODY:
I SOMETIMES think I should write a handbook for college admission officials titled ''How to Play the U.S. News & World Report Ranking Game, and Win!'' I would devote the first chapter to a tactic called ''SAT optional.'' 
 The idea is simple: tell applicants that they can choose whether or not to submit their SAT or ACT scores. Predictably, those applicants with low scores or those who know that they score poorly on standardized aptitude tests will not submit. Those with high scores will submit. When the college computes the mean SAT or ACT score of its enrolled students, voila! its average will have risen. And so too, it can fondly hope, will its status in the annual U.S. News & World Report's college rankings. 
My college requires applicants to submit their test scores, and it refuses to cooperate with the rankings. But among our peers, more and more institutions are adopting the SAT-optional strategy. This is not surprising. Once a few colleges adopt the tactic, their competitors feel pressure to follow suit, lest they suffer a drop in rank. And so a new front opens in the admissions arms race. 
 Those institutions that have adopted the SAT-optional strategy rationalize their decision by claiming that standardized tests are faulty measures of academic ability. The problem is that every indicator of academic ability used by college admission officers is imperfect. 
 Consider high school grade point averages. We all know brilliant students with low averages because they are bored by unchallenging classes. And conversely, these days a high grade point average is as likely to reveal rampant grade inflation as individual brilliance.
 Likewise, college essays and even graded high school papers may say more about the writing abilities of parents or professional coaches than of students. Interviews are notoriously unreliable, with different interviewers giving widely divergent scores.
 Standardized tests, for all their recognized imperfections, are carefully designed and tested to measure such basic intellectual skills as reading comprehension, vocabulary, critical thinking, computational ability and quantitative reasoning. Are admissions officers at SAT-optional universities saying that the test scores do not provide probative evidence of the possession of these skills? Are they saying that these skills are not relevant to success in the educational program of their colleges? Neither claim is remotely plausible.
 Moreover, if standardized test scores really are so imperfect, we should scrap them altogether. It's illogical to count a test score if it is high but ignore it if it is low. 
 Those who advocate making test scores optional sometimes argue that individual applicants know best whether their test scores are good measures of their academic abilities. But how can a high school senior know this? We all believe that we are better than our test scores and, for that matter, our grade point averages, our writing samples and our interview performances. But wishing doesn't make it so.
 Those who drop SAT or ACT requirements say that doing so helps open admissions to more members of certain racial, ethnic and socioeconomic groups that tend, on average, to score lower on these tests. Dropping the requirement encourages such students to apply and makes it easier for the college to admit them. 
 But if the scores on these tests are in fact evidence of academically relevant skills, shouldn't the college know how much of a deficit the student will need to overcome if he or she is admitted?
 The college isn't doing any favor to applicants by pretending that these skills are not important, or that the beneficiaries of these policies will not have to compete with students possessing those skills in abundance. An institution that, commendably, seeks to enroll more minority and lower-income students can do so by giving less weight to SAT or ACT scores, either across the board or in selective cases. But concealing the applicants' test scores is just willful blindness.
 Making SAT scores optional is the latest instance of a disheartening trend in college admissions. In the rush to climb the pecking order, educational institutions are adopting practices, and rationalizations for those practices, unworthy of the intellectual rigor they seek to instill in their students.

HEADLINE: Broadest Measure of Foreign Trade Deficit Widened 2.4% in Second Quarter 

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
The Commerce Department reported Monday that the deficit in the current account, the broadest measure of foreign trade, rose to $218.4 billion in the second quarter, an increase of 2.4 percent over the deficit in the first three months of the year. 
 The current account is the broadest measure of foreign trade because it covers not only trade in goods and services but also investment flows between countries. The deficit represents the amount the United States must borrow from foreigners to cover the shortfall between exports and imports.
The deficits through the first six months of this year put the country on track for a fifth consecutive annual deficit, surpassing the $791.5 billion of last year. The record for a single quarter was a $223.1 billion imbalance in the October-to-December period last year.
 So far, foreigners have been happy to hold dollars in payment for American purchases of cars, televisions and foreign oil. But the concern is what would happen should foreigners at some point decide they want to hold less in dollar-denominated assets.
 A rush for the exits by foreigners could send United States stock prices and the value of the dollar plunging and send interest rates higher.
 For the second quarter, the current-account deficit as a percentage of the overall economy stood at 6.6 percent, the same level as the first quarter.
 For the second quarter, the deficit in goods rose to $210.6 billion, an increase of $2.6 billion from the first quarter, reflecting in part the surge in oil prices. The surplus on services narrowed slightly to $16.8 billion.
 The United States recorded a record deficit on investment flows of $4.2 billion. That meant that foreigners earned more on their investments in the United States than Americans earned on their overseas investments.

HEADLINE: Inflation Fears and Rising Oil Prices Bring Rally to a Halt 

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks failed to extend last week's rally yesterday as oil rose the most this month and inflation concerns spurred investors to sell shares of retailers, the market's best performers in September.
 Home Depot, the home improvement chain, led the Dow Jones industrial average lower after Credit Suisse cut its rating, citing potential earnings shortfalls because of a housing slowdown.
Ford Motor fell for a third day after J. P. Morgan Chase analysts said the company's 2006 losses might be larger than forecast. 
 ''You're going to have two things working against these stocks,'' said Bart Barnett, head of equity trading at Morgan Keegan in Memphis. ''First, that they've had a great run. Second, that obviously higher oil prices are inherently negative for the consumer.''
 Stocks swung between gains and losses throughout the day amid concern that a report on wholesale prices today would show that inflation remains a threat. The Federal Reserve makes its next decision on interest rates tomorrow after leaving them unchanged last month for the first time in two years.
 The Dow fell 5.77 points, or 0.1 percent, to 11,555. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.31 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,321.18. Both benchmarks ended last week at their highest since May 10. The Nasdaq index added 0.16 points, to 2,235.75.
 Signs of slowing inflation have pushed the S.& P. 500 within 0.3 percent of a five-year high and have reduced the chances the Fed will resume raising rates. The S.& P. 500 last week had its best week in a month after consumer prices increased in August by half the pace of the previous month and oil prices tumbled.
 A measure of retailers fell 0.5 percent among two dozen industry groups in the S& P. 500. So far this month, retailers have gained 8.1 percent as a decline in oil prices has allayed concern that consumer spending will falter.
 Crude oil for October delivery rose yesterday on concern that a dispute between Iran and the United States about Iran's nuclear program would intensify and jeopardize oil supplies. The contract closed up 0.7 percent at $63.80 a barrel, the biggest gain since Aug. 24.
 Home Depot was the worst performer on the Dow, losing 64 cents, to $36.58. A Credit Suisse analyst, Gary Balter, cut the shares to neutral from outperform.
 Ford tumbled 20 cents, to $7.82. Losses this year ''are likely to be far wider than current expectations,'' a J. P. Morgan analyst, Himanshu Patel, wrote to clients.
 Sharper Image, a seller of products like robotic vacuum cleaners, dropped 34 cents, to $9.35. The company said it would restate results for the three years that ended in January 2006 after reviewing its stock option practices. Sharper Image also said its loss for the second quarter, compared with a year ago, widened before an income tax benefit.
 Applied Materials rose 58 cents, to $17.78, after saying it would buy back $5 billion in stock over three years.
 Higher crude prices gave energy shares a lift. A measure of oil-related companies advanced 2.6 percent for the best performance among the 10 industry groups in the S.& P. 500.
 Exxon Mobil added $1.65, to $66.30 for the Dow's best performance. Chevron rose $1.06, to $62.85. Even with yesterday's gain, energy shares are down 4 percent this month as oil prices have slumped 9.2 percent.
 The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 4/32, to 100 17/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.80, from 4.79 on Friday.
